labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: ci-cd
labels.description: Related to Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

issue.body:
### ðŸ“š Document AI prompt construction and model usage

**Problem Description:**
The `ai-enhancements.json` file currently logs token usage and AI budget, but lacks crucial details regarding the AI enhancement process. Specifically, there is no documentation or logging of:
- How the AI prompts were constructed.
- The specific Claude AI models used for each enhancement.
- Any human intervention or review steps in the AI content generation.

This lack of transparency hinders reproducibility, debugging, and continuous improvement of the AI enhancement pipeline.

**Remediation:**
Implement mechanisms to document and log the details of AI prompt construction and model usage. This could involve:
- Modifying `claude-enhancer.js` to log the full prompts sent to the Claude API.
- Recording the specific Claude model version used for each enhancement.
- Documenting any manual review or intervention steps in the workflow.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- The documentation clearly explains the prompt engineering strategy.
- The `ai-enhancements.json` or a related log file includes details on prompts and model versions used.
- The workflow allows for traceability of AI-generated content back to its generation parameters.

### Architecture Documentation

This issue primarily involves enhancing the logging and metadata capture within the AI enhancement pipeline. The `claude-enhancer.js` script will be the central point of modification, as it orchestrates the prompt construction and API calls. The captured metadata will be stored alongside the AI-enhanced content in `ai-enhancements.json` or a new dedicated metadata file.

**Key Integration Points:**
-   **`claude-enhancer.js`:** Modifications will be made within the methods that construct and send prompts to Claude (e.g., `enhanceProfessionalSummary`, `enhanceSkillsSection`, `enhanceExperience`, `generateStrategicInsights`).
-   **`AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js`:** This module already provides metadata about the constructed prompt (e.g., `prompt_type`, `creativity_level`, `few_shot_examples_used`). This metadata should be captured and logged.
-   **`ClaudeApiClient.js`:** This module makes the actual API calls. It can be extended to capture the Claude model version used and potentially log the full API request/response (for debugging, not for production logging of sensitive data).
-   **`ai-enhancements.json`:** This file will be extended to include new fields for prompt metadata, model version, and potentially a reference to a more detailed prompt log.

### Risk Assessment

-   **Data Volume:** Logging full prompts and responses can significantly increase the size of `ai-enhancements.json` or related log files. This needs to be managed (e.g., rotation, compression, or separate detailed logs).
-   **Sensitive Information:** Ensure that no sensitive user data is inadvertently logged in plain text within prompts or responses. Prompt engineering should already mitigate this, but it's a risk to be aware of.
-   **Performance Impact:** Excessive logging could introduce minor performance overhead, though likely negligible for this application.

### Testing Strategy

-   **Unit Tests:** Develop unit tests for the metadata capture logic, ensuring that the correct prompt details and model versions are being recorded. Mock API calls to verify the logging of prompt structures.
-   **Integration Tests:** Run end-to-end tests of the AI enhancement pipeline and verify that `ai-enhancements.json` (or the new metadata file) contains the expected prompt and model usage details.
-   **Manual Inspection:** Manually inspect the generated `ai-enhancements.json` files to confirm the accuracy and completeness of the logged metadata.
-   **Regression Testing:** Ensure that adding logging does not break existing functionality or introduce new bugs.

### Resource Requirements

-   **Development Expertise:** Familiarity with Node.js/JavaScript, Claude API, and data logging best practices.
-   **Storage:** Minimal additional storage for log files.

**Priority:** This is a critical documentation and transparency enhancement. It is currently **P1: High**, which is appropriate.

I have expanded the grooming of this issue to include deeper technical detail, as per Phase 2 of the grooming plan. Key additions include:

-   **Risk Assessment:** Identified potential challenges related to data volume, sensitive information, and performance impact.
-   **Testing Strategy:** Outlined comprehensive unit, integration, and manual inspection approaches.
-   **Resource Requirements:** Identified development expertise and storage needs.

This enhanced grooming provides a much more comprehensive foundation for development, addressing potential challenges and outlining a robust testing strategy.

issue.title: feat: Ensure narrative coherence and tone consistency in AI-enhanced content

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

issue.body:
### âœ¨ feat: Ensure narrative coherence and tone consistency in AI-enhanced content

**Problem Description:**
The AI-enhanced content, particularly the professional summary and experience descriptions, needs to consistently maintain narrative coherence and a professional tone. Currently, the AI might sometimes produce content that is verbose, includes meta-commentary, or deviates from a concise, impactful narrative suitable for a CV.

**Current Implementation:**
The `claude-enhancer.js` script (e.g., `enhanceProfessionalSummary` method, lines 300-330 for `creativityStrategies`) uses the `CREATIVITY_LEVEL` to select a persona, approach, tone, and focus for the AI's response. This is intended to influence narrative coherence and tone consistency.

However, inspection of `data/ai-enhancements.json` (e.g., `professional_summary.enhanced` lines 10-20) shows that the AI's output can still be verbose and include meta-commentary about the enhancement process, rather than just the concise, enhanced content. This indicates that while the AI is attempting to provide a compelling summary, the output format is not yet perfectly aligned with a concise, coherent narrative for direct CV integration.

**Proposed Solution:**
Refine prompt engineering and post-processing to ensure AI-enhanced content consistently maintains narrative coherence and a professional, concise tone.

**Key Considerations:**
*   **Prompt Engineering Refinement:**
    *   **Clearer Instructions:** Provide more explicit instructions to Claude to generate only the desired content, without meta-commentary or explanations of its process.
    *   **Few-Shot Examples:** Provide examples of concise, coherent, and professionally toned summaries and descriptions (leveraging Issue #96).
    *   **System Prompts:** Further refine system prompts (leveraging Issue #92) to reinforce the desired persona and output characteristics.
    *   **XML Tag Structuring:** Utilize XML tags (leveraging Issue #97) to clearly delineate the expected output section, minimizing extraneous text.
*   **Post-Processing:** Implement a post-processing step in `claude-enhancer.js` to strip any remaining meta-commentary or extraneous text from the AI's response before saving it.
*   **Content Length Control:** Explore mechanisms to control the length of AI-generated paragraphs and sections (related to Issue #76).

**Acceptance Criteria:**
*   AI-generated professional summaries and experience descriptions are consistently concise and free of meta-commentary.
*   The tone of AI-enhanced content is consistently professional and aligned with the selected creativity level.
*   Narrative flow is maintained across enhanced sections.

**Potential Progress:**
An existing mechanism to influence tone and coherence is in place. However, significant refinement of prompt engineering and potential post-processing is needed to achieve consistent, concise, and coherent output. This issue is closely related to and can benefit from progress on Issues #92, #96, #97, and #76.

### Architecture Documentation

This enhancement will primarily involve modifications to the prompt engineering within `claude-enhancer.js` and potentially the addition of a post-processing utility. The core data flow (input CV data -> Claude API -> `ai-enhancements.json` -> frontend) will remain the same, but the quality of the data within `ai-enhancements.json` will significantly improve.

**Key Integration Points:**
-   **`claude-enhancer.js`:** The `enhanceProfessionalSummary`, `enhanceSkillsSection`, and `enhanceExperience` methods will be the primary targets for prompt refinement. A new post-processing function might be added here or in a new utility module.
-   **`AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js`:** This module will be used to construct the refined XML prompts, incorporating clearer instructions, few-shot examples, and potentially new tags for length control.
-   **`PromptLibraryManager.js`:** Will manage any new few-shot examples or persona refinements.

### Risk Assessment

-   **Over-constraining AI:** Overly aggressive prompt engineering or post-processing might inadvertently strip valuable context or creativity from Claude's responses. Careful balancing and iterative testing are required.
-   **Maintaining Nuance:** Ensuring conciseness and consistency without losing the nuanced meaning or impact of the original content can be challenging.
-   **Performance Impact:** Complex post-processing or very long few-shot examples could increase Claude API latency and token usage.

### Testing Strategy

-   **Unit Tests:** Develop unit tests for any new post-processing functions. Enhance existing tests for `claude-enhancer.js` to specifically assert the absence of meta-commentary and adherence to length/conciseness criteria in the output (mocking Claude API responses).
-   **Manual Review:** Extensive manual review of AI-generated content across different creativity levels and input scenarios to assess narrative coherence, tone consistency, and conciseness.
-   **A/B Testing:** Consider A/B testing different prompt engineering strategies to quantitatively measure improvements in output quality and user satisfaction.
-   **Regression Testing:** Ensure that changes do not negatively impact other aspects of Claude's output or the overall CV generation process.

### Resource Requirements

-   **Development Expertise:** Strong understanding of prompt engineering best practices, Claude API, and JavaScript development.
-   **Claude API Tokens:** Potential increase in token usage during prompt refinement and testing phases.

**Priority:** This is a critical enhancement for the quality and usability of the AI-generated content. It is currently **P1: High**, which is appropriate.

issue.body:
### âœ¨ Implement automated suggestions module based on market trends

**Problem Description:**
The `content-analysis.pdf` document highlights the importance of aligning strategic suggestions with market trends (e.g., focusing on LLMs, MLOps, edge AI, AI ethics). While the AI enhancement process may implicitly consider these, there isn't an explicit, automated module that generates actionable suggestions based on these trends. This limits the system's ability to provide proactive, data-driven career guidance.

**Current Implementation:**
The `claude-enhancer.js` script (e.g., `enhanceProfessionalSummary` lines 341-365, `enhanceSkillsSection` lines 530-570) includes "MARKET CONTEXT (2025)" within its prompts to inform the AI's content generation. The `generateStrategicInsights` method (lines 800-970) is designed to produce strategic insights, and `data/ai-enhancements.json` (e.g., `enhancement_summary.recommendations` lines 78-81) includes high-level recommendations.

However, the current implementation lacks:
*   An explicit, automated module that *generates actionable suggestions* for the user based on market trends.
*   Integration with *external data sources* for real-time market trend analysis (beyond hardcoded prompt context).
*   A dedicated, structured output section in `ai-enhancements.json` specifically for these actionable suggestions.

**Proposed Solution:**
Develop and integrate an automated suggestions module that leverages market trend analysis to provide actionable recommendations for CV content optimization and career development.

**Key Considerations:**
*   **Market Trend Data Acquisition:**
    *   Integrate with external data sources on industry trends (e.g., job board APIs, industry reports, academic research - potentially leveraging Issue #93 for web scraping).
    *   Develop a mechanism to regularly update and process this market trend data.
*   **AI-Driven Suggestion Generation:**
    *   Enhance the AI's prompt engineering (e.g., in `claude-enhancer.js`) to explicitly generate specific, actionable suggestions aligned with market demands. This could involve new prompt structures or dedicated AI calls.
    *   Leverage the "Tool Use" paradigm (Issue #94) to ensure structured output for these suggestions.
*   **Output Integration:**
    *   Create a dedicated section in the `ai-enhancements.json` output for these strategic suggestions (e.g., `strategic_recommendations: []`).
    *   Integrate these suggestions into the generated CV interface for user visibility.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
*   The system can identify and incorporate current AI/ML market trends into its enhancement suggestions.
*   An automated module generates specific, actionable recommendations for CV content based on these trends.
*   The recommendations help differentiate the professional profile and highlight unique achievements.
*   These recommendations are clearly presented in the AI enhancement output.

**Potential Progress:**
The AI is currently informed by market context in its prompts, and some high-level recommendations are generated. However, a formalized, automated module for generating *actionable* suggestions based on dynamic market trends is not yet implemented. This issue is dependent on Issue #93 (web scraping) for external data sources and can benefit from advanced prompt engineering (Issue #33, #94).
### Architecture Documentation

This module will primarily reside within the existing AI enhancement pipeline, likely extending `claude-enhancer.js` or introducing a new dedicated module (e.g., `market-intelligence-analyzer.js`) that integrates with it. It will consume market trend data (potentially from a new data source or an enhanced `github-data-miner.js` output) and the candidate's CV data. The output will be structured JSON, integrated into `ai-enhancements.json`, and then consumed by the frontend for display.

**Key Integration Points:**
-   **Data Ingestion Layer:** A new component (e.g., Python script or Node.js module) responsible for fetching and processing market trend data from external APIs or scraped sources.
-   **`claude-enhancer.js`:** Will be modified to incorporate the market trend data into the prompt context for Claude when generating strategic insights or enhancing specific sections.
-   **`ai-enhancements.json`:** The output of this module (actionable suggestions) will be added as a new top-level key (e.g., `market_driven_suggestions`).
-   **Frontend (`assets/script.js`, `index.html`):** Will need updates to display the new `market_driven_suggestions` in a user-friendly format.

### Risk Assessment

-   **Data Source Reliability:** Reliance on external APIs or web scraping introduces risks related to data availability, API rate limits, changes in data format, and bot detection (for scraping). Robust error handling, retry mechanisms, and monitoring will be crucial.
-   **AI Hallucination/Relevance:** Ensuring Claude generates truly actionable and relevant suggestions based on potentially abstract market trend data is challenging. Careful prompt engineering and validation will be required to prevent generic or unhelpful recommendations.
-   **Performance/Cost:** Frequent API calls to external market data sources or extensive Claude interactions could impact performance and increase operational costs. Caching strategies and efficient data processing will be important.
-   **Bias in Market Data:** Market trend data itself can contain biases (e.g., favoring certain demographics or skill sets). The system should ideally incorporate mechanisms to detect and mitigate such biases in the suggestions generated.

### Testing Strategy

-   **Unit Tests:** Develop comprehensive unit tests for the new data acquisition module, ensuring correct data fetching, parsing, and structuring. Test the logic for generating suggestions within `claude-enhancer.js` (mocking Claude API calls and market data inputs).
-   **Integration Tests:** Test the end-to-end flow, from market data acquisition to the generation and display of suggestions in the `ai-enhancements.json` and frontend. This will require setting up mock external APIs or using pre-recorded data.
-   **Manual Review/A/B Testing:** Critical manual review of AI-generated suggestions for relevance, actionability, and absence of bias. Consider A/B testing different prompt strategies or data sources to optimize suggestion quality.
-   **Regression Testing:** Ensure that implementing this module does not negatively impact existing CV enhancement functionalities.

### Resource Requirements

-   **External APIs/Data Sources:** Identification and potential subscription to market trend data APIs (e.g., job market analytics, industry reports). This may involve financial cost.
-   **Claude API Tokens:** Increased usage of Claude API for generating suggestions will consume more tokens, impacting budget.
-   **Development Expertise:** Requires expertise in web scraping (if applicable), API integration, Node.js/JavaScript development, and advanced Claude prompt engineering.

**Priority:** This is a significant enhancement for providing proactive career guidance. It is currently **P1: High**, which is appropriate.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The current visualization of the Skills section in the CV is basic, primarily displaying skills as a simple list. To provide a more engaging and informative overview of the user's technical capabilities and proficiency levels, the visualization needs to be enhanced.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`index.html`:** Contains the HTML structure for the Skills section (`<section id="skills">`, `<div class="skills-container" id="skills-container">`).
-   **`assets/script.js`:** The `initializeSkillsSection()` function is responsible for dynamically populating the `skills-container`. It currently iterates through skill categories and individual skills, displaying their names and a `skill-level` (presumably a percentage).
-   **Data Source:** Skill data is sourced from `this.cvData?.skills` and `this.getDefaultSkills()`, which might include proficiency levels.

This issue aims to transform the static skills list into a dynamic and visually appealing representation of technical expertise.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Enhanced Visuals:** The Skills section utilizes more engaging visual elements (e.g., progress bars, radar charts, heatmaps, or interactive tags) to represent skill proficiency and categories.
-   **Clear Proficiency Representation:** Proficiency levels are clearly and intuitively communicated (e.g., visual indicators, distinct styling for different levels).
-   **Categorization Clarity:** If skills are categorized, the visualization clearly distinguishes between categories.
-   **Interactivity (Optional):** Users can interact with the visualization (e.g., hover for details, filter by category).
-   **Responsiveness:** The enhanced visualization adapts gracefully to different screen sizes.
-   **Performance:** The new visualization loads quickly and does not negatively impact overall page performance.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Research Visualization Options:**
    *   Explore various JavaScript charting libraries (e.g., Chart.js, D3.js, ApexCharts) or CSS-only visualization techniques suitable for skill representation.
    *   Consider different visual metaphors (e.g., skill clouds, proficiency bars, radial charts).
2.  **Data Preparation:**

    *   **JavaScript:** In `assets/script.js`:
        *   Update `initializeSkillsSection()` to render the new visualization.
        *   Integrate the chosen charting library or implement custom rendering logic.
        *   Add event listeners for any interactive elements.

### Dependency Mapping

-   **#72 (Concatenated technology stacks lack separators):** If the solution involves rendering skills as distinct elements, fixing #72 might be a prerequisite or a complementary task.
-   **#73 (Bullet points are presented as plain paragraphs with hyphens):** Similar to #72, if the visualization uses list structures, this issue might be related.
-   **#81 (Replace Placeholder Metrics):** If skill proficiency is derived from GitHub data, ensuring that data is accurate is important.

### Effort Estimation

**Large.** Implementing a custom or library-based data visualization can be complex, involving data manipulation, rendering logic, and styling. Researching the best approach and ensuring performance will also take time. Estimated time: 2-4 days.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

While the CV interface has some basic responsive elements, the overall user experience on mobile devices is not optimal. Layouts may break, content can be difficult to read, and navigation might be cumbersome, leading to a degraded experience for users accessing the CV on smartphones and tablets.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`index.html` and `watch-me-work.html`:** Both HTML files include the `<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">` tag, which is foundational for responsive design.
-   **`assets/styles.css` and `assets/watch-me-work.css`:** These CSS files already contain `@media` queries and utilize CSS Grid for layout (`display: grid;`), indicating an existing, albeit potentially incomplete, responsive design implementation.
-   **Current Gaps:** The issue suggests that despite these elements, the layout does not adapt gracefully across all mobile breakpoints, or specific components are not optimized for touch interfaces and smaller screens.

This issue aims to deliver a seamless and intuitive user experience across all device sizes, with a particular focus on mobile responsiveness.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Adaptive Layout:** The CV layout and content adapt gracefully to various screen sizes, from mobile phones (e.g., 320px width) to large desktops, without horizontal scrolling.
-   **Readability and Usability:** All text is legible, and interactive elements (buttons, links) are easily tappable and usable on mobile devices.
-   **Image and Media Scaling:** Images and other media assets scale appropriately to fit the screen size without distortion or excessive loading times.
-   **Mobile Navigation:** Navigation (if applicable) is intuitive and accessible on mobile devices (e.g., a responsive navigation menu).
-   **Performance Optimization:** The CV loads quickly and scrolls smoothly on mobile devices.
-   **Cross-Device Compatibility:** The responsive design functions correctly across a range of mobile browsers and devices.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Comprehensive Responsiveness Audit:**
    *   Use browser developer tools to simulate various mobile devices (e.g., iPhone SE, Galaxy S8, iPad Mini) and identify specific sections or components where the layout breaks, content overflows, or usability is compromised.
    *   Document all identified issues with screenshots and specific breakpoints.
2.  **Refine and Expand Existing CSS:**
    *   Review and enhance existing `@media` queries in `assets/styles.css` and `assets/watch-me-work.css` to cover a wider range of breakpoints.
    *   Apply `flexbox` or `grid` properties more extensively for flexible and adaptable layouts, ensuring content reflows naturally.
    *   Adjust `font-size`, `padding`, and `margin` values using relative units (e.g., `rem`, `em`, `vw`) or within media queries for optimal readability on smaller screens.
3.  **Optimize Images and Media:**
    *   Ensure all images are responsive by default (e.g., `img { max-width: 100%; height: auto; display: block; }`).
    *   Consider using `<picture>` elements or `srcset` attributes for serving optimized image sizes based on device capabilities.
4.  **Mobile-First Design Principles:** Where appropriate, consider refactoring CSS to adopt a mobile-first approach, styling for small screens first and then progressively enhancing for larger screens.
5.  **Performance Considerations:**
    *   Minify CSS and JavaScript files to reduce load times.
    *   Optimize image assets further.
    *   Consider lazy loading for images or sections that are not immediately visible on page load.
6.  **Thorough Cross-Device Testing:**
    *   Test the implemented changes on actual mobile devices or a wide range of emulators to catch any device-specific rendering issues or touch interaction problems.

### Dependency Mapping

-   This is primarily a frontend issue and does not have direct dependencies on backend or AI-related issues.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium to Large.** While foundational elements are present, a comprehensive overhaul for optimal mobile experience can be time-consuming. It involves detailed CSS adjustments, potential refactoring of HTML structure for better responsiveness, and thorough cross-device testing. Estimated time: 2-4 days.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

Certain sections of the generated CV, particularly the professional summary and experience details, contain overly long and dense paragraphs. This makes the content difficult to read, scan, and digest, negatively impacting the overall readability and ATS-friendliness of the CV.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`claude-enhancer.js` (`.github/scripts/claude-enhancer.js`):** This script is responsible for generating and enhancing the professional summary (`enhanceProfessionalSummary`) and experience descriptions (`enhanceExperience`). The LLM (Claude) might be generating verbose responses that are not being post-processed for readability.
-   **`cv-generator.js` (`.github/scripts/cv-generator.js`):** This script assembles the CV content, including the AI-enhanced parts. It might not have mechanisms to break down long paragraphs.
-   **`assets/script.js`:** This script is responsible for rendering the content in the frontend. It displays the text as it receives it.

This issue aims to improve the readability of the CV by ensuring that long paragraphs are broken down into more digestible chunks, potentially using shorter sentences, bullet points, or sub-sections.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Improved Readability:** Long paragraphs in the professional summary and experience details are broken down into shorter, more scannable chunks.
-   **Sentence Length Optimization:** Average sentence length is reduced in key sections.
-   **Bullet Point Utilization:** Where appropriate, information is presented using bullet points instead of dense paragraphs.
-   **ATS-Friendliness:** The content remains ATS-friendly and retains its impact after being broken down.
-   **Configurable Chunking:** (Optional) A mechanism to configure the maximum paragraph/sentence length or the preferred chunking strategy.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Refine Claude Prompt for Conciseness:**
    *   Modify the Claude prompts in `claude-enhancer.js` (for professional summary and experience enhancement) to explicitly instruct the LLM to generate concise paragraphs, use shorter sentences, and utilize bullet points where appropriate.
    *   Provide few-shot examples that demonstrate the desired chunking and readability.
2.  **Implement Post-Processing Logic:**
    *   In `claude-enhancer.js` (or a new utility module), implement a post-processing function that takes a long text string and breaks it down.
    *   This could involve:
        *   Splitting paragraphs by sentence and rejoining them into shorter paragraphs.
        *   Identifying lists within paragraphs and converting them to actual bullet points (if not already done by Claude).
        *   Using NLP techniques to summarize or rephrase sentences for conciseness.
3.  **Integrate Post-Processing:** Apply this post-processing function to the AI-generated professional summary and experience details before they are saved or used by `cv-generator.js`.
4.  **Develop Unit Tests:**
    *   Add unit tests for the post-processing function, ensuring it correctly breaks down long paragraphs and maintains content integrity.
    *   Test with various lengths and complexities of input text.

### Dependency Mapping

-   **#97 (Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts):** Prompt refinement will utilize the XML structure.
-   **#96 (Integrate Few-Shot Prompting into AI Enhancement):** New few-shot examples will be crucial for guiding Claude's output style.
-   **#82 (Align AI summary with experience chronology):** Ensuring chronological alignment should be maintained during chunking.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** This requires careful prompt engineering and potentially some text processing logic. Testing for readability and impact after chunking can be nuanced. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

issue.title: bug: Provide feedback for external link failures

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: P3: Low
labels.description: Low priority; address when time permits

labels.name: ux
labels.description: Related to User Experience design and testing.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

When users click on external links within the CV (e.g., GitHub, LinkedIn, project demos, achievement links), there is no feedback mechanism if the link is broken, unreachable, or takes a long time to load. This leads to a poor user experience, as users are left wondering if their click registered or if the destination is valid.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`index.html`:** Contains static external links (e.g., contact links to GitHub, LinkedIn, email, PDF download).
-   **`assets/script.js`:** Dynamically generates external links for projects (`initializeProjectsSection`) and achievements (`initializeAchievementsSection`).
-   **Browser Behavior:** By default, browsers handle link clicks by navigating to the new URL. For external links, this typically opens a new tab (`target="_blank"`). There's no built-in feedback for link failures.

This issue aims to improve user experience by providing clear feedback on the status of external links.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Visual Feedback on Click:** When an external link is clicked, a subtle visual indicator (e.g., a temporary loading spinner, a change in cursor, or a brief text message) appears near the link.
-   **Success/Failure Notification:**
    *   If the link successfully loads (new tab opens), the visual indicator disappears.
    *   If the link fails to load (e.g., 404, network error), a clear, non-intrusive error message is displayed to the user (e.g., a small tooltip or a temporary message in a designated area).
-   **Timeout Handling:** If an external link takes an unusually long time to load, provide feedback indicating a potential delay.
-   **Accessibility:** Feedback mechanisms are accessible to users with disabilities.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Identify All External Links:**
    *   Scan `index.html` for `<a>` tags with `target="_blank"`.
    *   Review `assets/script.js` for dynamic link generation (e.g., `project.github`, `project.demo`, `achievement.link`).
2.  **Implement Event Listeners:**
    *   Attach event listeners (e.g., `click` event) to all identified external links.
    *   Consider using event delegation on a parent container to efficiently manage many links.
3.  **Feedback Mechanism:**
    *   **Visual Indicator:** On click, add a CSS class to the link or append a small loading icon next to it.
    *   **Error Detection:** This is the most challenging part. Direct detection of external link failures via JavaScript is limited due to cross-origin security policies. Potential strategies:
        *   **Proxy/Backend Check (Advanced):** For critical links, a backend endpoint could be used to check link validity, but this adds complexity.
        *   **Simple Timeout:** Assume failure if a new tab doesn't load within a reasonable time (e.g., 5-10 seconds). This is a heuristic and not a true failure detection.
        *   **User-Agent Feedback:** Encourage users to report broken links via a simple feedback form.
    *   **Success/Failure Display:** Use temporary CSS classes or dynamically created `<span>` elements to display messages.

### Dependency Mapping

-   This issue is primarily a frontend UX enhancement and does not have direct dependencies on other major issues.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** Implementing robust external link failure detection is challenging due to browser security models. A basic feedback mechanism (visual indicator, simple timeout) is Medium, while a more comprehensive solution would be Large. Estimated time: 1-2 days for basic implementation.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The current display of activity metrics (e.g., Activity Score, AI Credibility) is static. To provide a richer user experience and deeper insights, these metrics should be made interactive, allowing users to explore underlying data or trends.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`index.html`:** Contains the HTML structure for displaying live stats (`<div class="live-stats">`, `id="activity-score"`, `id="credibility-score"`).
-   **`assets/script.js`:** The `initializeLiveStats()` and `updateLiveStats()` functions are responsible for fetching and updating these metrics. The data is likely sourced from `activity-summary.json` or similar processed data files.
-   **`watch-me-work.html` and `assets/watch-me-work.js`:** These files also deal with live metrics and could provide inspiration or reusable components for interactive displays.

This issue aims to transform static metric displays into dynamic, engaging, and informative interactive elements.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Interactive Metric Display:** Key metrics (e.g., Activity Score, AI Credibility) are interactive.
-   **Tooltip/Detail View:** Hovering over or clicking a metric reveals additional details, definitions, or underlying data points (e.g., a breakdown of how the score is calculated, historical trends).
-   **Visual Enhancements:** Metrics are presented with visual cues (e.g., progress bars, small charts, color-coding) that dynamically reflect their values.
-   **User Engagement:** The interactive elements encourage users to explore their data more deeply.
-   **Performance:** Interactive elements load quickly and do not negatively impact overall page performance.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Identify Target Metrics:** Determine which metrics would benefit most from interactivity (e.g., Activity Score, AI Credibility, possibly others from `watch-me-work.html`).
2.  **Choose Interaction Method:** Decide on the primary interaction (e.g., hover for tooltip, click for modal/expanded view).
3.  **Implement Data Fetching (if needed):** If the interactive details require more data than what's immediately available, ensure the necessary data is loaded (e.g., from `activity-summary.json` or other data files).
4.  **Frontend Implementation:**
    *   **HTML:** Modify `index.html` to wrap metrics in interactive elements (e.g., `<a>` tags, `<div>` with event listeners).
    *   **CSS:** Add styling for interactive states (hover effects, tooltip appearance).
    *   **JavaScript:** In `assets/script.js`:
        *   Add event listeners to the metric elements.
        *   Implement functions to display tooltips or modals with detailed information.
        *   Consider using a lightweight charting library (e.g., Chart.js, ApexCharts) for historical trends if applicable.
5.  **Test Responsiveness:** Ensure interactivity works well on different screen sizes.

### Dependency Mapping

-   **#80 (Implausible net lines calculation):** If Activity Score relies on accurate underlying data, fixing #80 might be beneficial.
-   **#81 (Replace Placeholder Metrics):** This issue will benefit from having real, verified data to display interactively.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** Implementing interactive elements and potentially integrating a charting library will require moderate frontend development effort. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

issue.title: enhancement: Align AI summary with experience chronology

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P2: Medium
labels.description: Medium priority; address in due course

labels.name: content

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The AI-generated professional summary may not consistently align with the chronological flow and key milestones of the user's professional experience. This can lead to a disjointed narrative, where the summary highlights aspects that are not clearly supported or chronologically ordered by the detailed experience section, reducing the overall credibility and impact of the CV.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`claude-enhancer.js` (`.github/scripts/claude-enhancer.js`):** This script is responsible for generating the professional summary (`enhanceProfessionalSummary` method) and enhancing the experience section (`enhanceExperience` method). The issue likely lies in the prompt engineering for the summary, where the chronological aspect of experience is not sufficiently emphasized or utilized.
-   **`cv-generator.js` (`.github/scripts/cv-generator.js`):** This script consumes the enhanced summary and experience data. While it doesn't directly cause the misalignment, it relies on the quality of the AI-generated content.
-   **Data Flow:** The `enhanceProfessionalSummary` method receives `cvData` (which includes experience) and `activityMetrics`. The challenge is to ensure the LLM effectively synthesizes the chronological and impactful aspects of the experience into the summary.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Chronological Coherence:** The AI-generated professional summary accurately reflects the chronological progression and key milestones of the professional experience section.
-   **Key Achievement Integration:** The summary highlights achievements and responsibilities that are clearly supported by the detailed experience entries and their dates.
-   **Narrative Flow:** The summary seamlessly introduces and sets the stage for the detailed experience section, creating a cohesive career narrative.
-   **Prompt Refinement:** The Claude prompt for professional summary generation is refined to explicitly guide the LLM in considering chronological experience.
-   **Unit Test Coverage:** Relevant unit tests are added or updated to verify the chronological alignment of the summary with experience.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Refine Prompt for Professional Summary:**
    *   Modify the Claude prompt used by `enhanceProfessionalSummary` in `claude-enhancer.js`.
    *   Explicitly instruct Claude to analyze the provided `experience` data and synthesize a summary that respects chronological order and highlights key career progression points.
    *   Consider adding few-shot examples that demonstrate summaries aligned with chronological experience.
    *   Emphasize the importance of connecting summary claims to specific, dated experiences.

-   **#98 (Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library):** Any new prompt components or examples will be managed here.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** This requires careful prompt engineering and potentially some pre-processing of experience data. Testing for chronological accuracy can also be nuanced. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

issue.title: ðŸŽ­ feat(claude): Utilize System Prompts for Persona-Driven AI Responses

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

To ensure Claude AI responses are consistently aligned with specific roles, tones, and domain expertise, the system needs to fully leverage System Prompts. Assigning a persona via the `system` parameter in the Messages API transforms Claude into a domain-specific expert, making its outputs more contextually appropriate and valuable.

### Technical Analysis

The project's prompt engineering framework and research documents strongly advocate for System Prompts:

-   **`docs/prompt_construction.md` and `docs/research/claude-prompt-engineering-framework.md`:** These documents detail the importance of System Prompts for establishing persona and tone, providing examples for different roles (e.g., "expert career coach", "meticulous financial analyst").
-   **`PromptLibraryManager.js` (`.github/scripts/enhancer-modules/prompt-library-manager.js`):** This module is designed to load and manage persona definitions from YAML files (e.g., `prompts/claude/v2.0/personas/senior-technical-recruiter.yaml`). It includes a `getPersona` method to retrieve these definitions.
-   **`AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` (`.github/scripts/enhancer-modules/advanced-xml-prompt-constructor.js`):** This module constructs the XML prompt, and its `buildPersonaContext` method is intended to integrate persona information into the prompt structure. However, the actual delivery of the System Prompt is via the `system` parameter of the Claude Messages API, not directly within the XML prompt body.
-   **`claude-enhancer.js` (`.github/scripts/claude-enhancer.js`):** This script makes the actual API calls to Claude. It currently constructs messages with `content` but does not explicitly use the `system` parameter.

This issue focuses on ensuring that the appropriate persona is dynamically selected and passed as a System Prompt to the Claude API when making requests, thereby controlling Claude's overall behavior and output style.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Dynamic Persona Selection:** The system can dynamically select the appropriate persona based on the task or context (e.g., a "Career Coach" persona for resume analysis, a "Technical Recruiter" for skill matching).
-   **System Prompt Integration:** The selected persona's definition is correctly passed as the `system` parameter in the Claude Messages API call.
-   **Consistent Tone and Expertise:** Claude's responses consistently reflect the assigned persona's tone, vocabulary, and analytical framework.
-   **Persona Management:** A clear process exists for adding, updating, and managing persona definitions within the prompt library.
-   **Unit Test Coverage:** Comprehensive unit tests are implemented to verify the correct selection and application of System Prompts.
-   **Documentation Alignment:** The implementation aligns with the System Prompt principles outlined in the project's prompt engineering documentation.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Refine Persona Definitions:**
    *   Ensure existing persona YAML files (`prompts/claude/v2.0/personas/`) are comprehensive and accurately define the desired roles, expertise, and tones.
    *   Add any missing persona definitions required for various AI enhancement tasks.
2.  **Modify Claude API Call Logic:**
    *   In `claude-enhancer.js` (or the module responsible for making the Claude API call, which is `ClaudeApiClient.js` within `enhancer-modules`), modify the API request to include the `system` parameter.
    *   The value of the `system` parameter should be dynamically retrieved from the `PromptLibraryManager.js` (via `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` or directly) based on the persona ID associated with the current task.
3.  **Integrate Persona Selection into Workflow:**
    *   Ensure that the AI enhancement workflow (e.g., `claude-enhancer.js` or the Python orchestration layer) can specify which persona to use for a given task.
4.  **Develop Comprehensive Unit Tests:**
    *   Create or enhance test files to verify the correct selection of personas and their inclusion in the Claude API call (mocking the API call).
    *   Test different persona selections and their impact on the simulated Claude API request.

### Dependency Mapping

This issue is highly dependent on:
-   **#98 (Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library):** Persona definitions are managed by the `PromptLibraryManager.js`.
-   **#97 (Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts):** While System Prompts are separate from the XML prompt body, they work in conjunction to guide Claude's behavior.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** The core persona management is in place, but integrating the `system` parameter into the API call and ensuring dynamic selection will require careful implementation and testing. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

issue.title: bug: Investigate and resolve npm warnings during dependency installation

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: tech-debt
labels.description: Technical debt that needs to be addressed

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Related to package dependencies and their management

issue.body:
Investigate and resolve all `npm` warnings that occur during dependency installation in the `.github/scripts` directory. These warnings, while not always critical, can indicate potential issues with dependency compatibility, deprecations, or inefficient package management, and can clutter CI logs.

**Key Considerations:**
*   **Identify Warnings:** Run `npm install` in `.github/scripts` and carefully review all warnings.
*   **Categorize Warnings:** Determine the nature of each warning (e.g., deprecated package, peer dependency mismatch, unmet optional dependency).
*   **Root Cause Analysis:** For each warning, identify the underlying cause.
*   **Prioritize:** Address warnings based on their potential impact on stability, security, or future maintainability.

**Proposed Solutions:**
*   **Update Dependencies:** Upgrade outdated packages to their latest compatible versions.
*   **Replace Deprecated Packages:** If a package is deprecated, find and migrate to a suitable alternative.
*   **Resolve Peer Dependency Issues:** Adjust `package.json` to correctly specify peer dependency ranges or install missing peer dependencies.
*   **Review `package-lock.json`:** Ensure the lock file is consistent with `package.json` and reflects the desired dependency tree.
*   **Document Ignored Warnings:** If certain warnings are deemed harmless and cannot be resolved, document the reason for ignoring them.

issue.title: bug: Print/Download PDF buttons are non-functional

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: generator
labels.description: Related to CV generation process

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: ux
labels.description: Related to User Experience design and testing.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The "Print CV" and "Download PDF" buttons on the CV interface are non-functional, preventing users from easily obtaining a physical copy or a portable digital version of their CV.

### Technical Analysis

-   **Print Button:** The "Print CV" button in `index.html` uses `onclick="window.print()"`. This is a standard browser function. If it's not working, potential causes include:
    *   JavaScript errors preventing the `onclick` event from firing.
    *   Browser-specific security restrictions.
    *   Conflicting CSS (`@media print`) that might hide content or make it unprintable.
-   **Download PDF Button:** The "Download PDF" button in `index.html` links directly to `assets/adrian-wedd-cv.pdf`. If this is non-functional, the most likely causes are:
    *   The PDF file (`assets/adrian-wedd-cv.pdf`) is missing from the repository or not being generated correctly.
    *   The path to the PDF file is incorrect.
-   **PDF Generation:** The `cv-generator.js` script (documented in `docs/jsdoc_output/github_scripts_cv-generator.js.html`) contains a `generatePDF()` function. This suggests that the PDF is intended to be pre-generated or generated as part of a build process. The non-functionality might stem from a failure in this generation process.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Print Functionality:** Clicking the "Print CV" button successfully opens the browser's print dialog with the CV content.
-   **PDF Download Functionality:** Clicking the "Download PDF" button successfully initiates the download of a valid PDF file of the CV.
-   **PDF Content Accuracy:** The downloaded PDF accurately reflects the content and styling of the online CV.
-   **Error Handling:** Appropriate feedback is provided to the user if print or download operations fail.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Verify Print Functionality:**
    *   Test `window.print()` directly in the browser console on `index.html`.
    *   Inspect `assets/script.js` for any JavaScript errors that might be preventing event handlers from firing.
    *   Review `assets/styles.css` for any `@media print` rules that might be inadvertently hiding content.
2.  **Verify PDF File Existence and Path:**
    *   Manually check if `assets/adrian-wedd-cv.pdf` exists in the repository.
    *   Confirm the path in `index.html` is correct.
3.  **Investigate PDF Generation Process:**
    *   Examine `cv-generator.js` and any associated build scripts or GitHub Actions workflows that are responsible for generating `adrian-wedd-cv.pdf`.
    *   Ensure the PDF generation process is running successfully and placing the file in the correct location.
    *   If the PDF is not being generated, debug the `generatePDF()` function and its dependencies (e.g., Puppeteer or similar headless browser tools).

### Dependency Mapping

-   This issue is primarily a frontend functionality bug, but its resolution may depend on the successful execution of backend PDF generation processes.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** The print functionality might be a quick fix, but debugging and ensuring the PDF generation process is robust could take more time. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

issue.title: enhancement: Integrate emerging skills and market trends

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P2: Medium
labels.description: Medium priority; address in due course

labels.name: content
labels.description: Related to content generation, quality, and analysis.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The CV generation system needs to dynamically integrate emerging skills and market trends into the CV content and enhancement process. Currently, the system might rely on static skill sets or lack mechanisms to adapt to the rapidly evolving job market, potentially making generated CVs less competitive or relevant.

### Technical Analysis

Several existing components are relevant to this enhancement:

-   **`activity-analyzer.js` (`.github/scripts/activity-analyzer.js`):** This script analyzes GitHub activity and identifies top programming languages and skills. It also includes placeholder methods like `assessMarketAlignment` and `assessMarketPosition` which are directly relevant to this issue.
-   **`claude-enhancer.js` (`.github/scripts/claude-enhancer.js`):** This script uses Claude for CV content enhancement. It already incorporates `MARKET CONTEXT` within its prompts (e.g., for professional summary and skills enhancement), but this context is currently static or broadly defined. It also has methods like `analyzeMarketPositioning`.
-   **`github-data-miner.js` (`.github/scripts/github-data-miner.js`):** This script mines GitHub for various forms of intelligence, which could be expanded to include market trend analysis.
-   **Python Modules (`src/python/data_processing/data_fusion.py`, `src/python/nlp/nlp_utils.py`):** These modules handle data fusion and NLP tasks, which could be used to process external market data or identify emerging skills from job descriptions.

This issue aims to make the integration of market trends and emerging skills dynamic and data-driven, ensuring the generated CVs are always optimized for current industry demands.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Dynamic Market Trend Integration:** The system can ingest and utilize up-to-date information on emerging skills and market trends.
-   **CV Content Adaptation:** AI-generated CV content (summaries, skills, experience) is dynamically adapted to highlight relevance to current market demands.
-   **Skill Gap Identification (Market-Driven):** The system can identify skill gaps based on market trends, not just individual activity.
-   **Market Alignment Scoring:** A mechanism exists to score the CV's alignment with current market trends.
-   **Data Source Integration:** Identify and integrate reliable external data sources for market trends and emerging skills (e.g., job board APIs, industry reports).
-   **Unit Test Coverage:** Comprehensive unit tests are implemented for any new or modified modules related to market trend integration.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Identify and Integrate Market Data Sources:**
    *   Research and select reliable APIs or data feeds for emerging skills and market trends (e.g., from job boards, industry analysis firms).
    *   Develop a new data acquisition module (e.g., `src/python/market_data_collector.py`) to fetch and process this data.
2.  **Enhance Data Fusion:**
    *   Update `data_processing/data_fusion.py` to incorporate market trend data into the overall intelligence profile.
3.  **Update Prompt Context:**
    *   Modify `claude-enhancer.js` to dynamically inject current market trends and emerging skills into the Claude prompts (e.g., within the `<market_context>` tag in the XML prompt).
    *   Leverage the `PromptLibraryManager.js` to manage market-related prompt components.
4.  **Refine Market Alignment Assessment:**
    *   Implement the logic for `assessMarketAlignment` and `assessMarketPosition` in `activity-analyzer.js` (or a new dedicated module) using the integrated market data.
    *   Develop a scoring mechanism to quantify the CV's market alignment.
5.  **Develop Unit Tests:**
    *   Add unit tests for the new data acquisition module and the market alignment assessment logic.

### Dependency Mapping

-   **#98 (Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library):** Essential for managing market-related prompt components.
-   **#97 (Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts):** Required for dynamically injecting market context into XML prompts.
-   **#96 (Integrate Few-Shot Prompting into AI Enhancement):** Few-shot examples can be used to guide Claude on how to integrate market trends into narratives.
-   **#81 (Replace Placeholder Metrics):** This issue will benefit from accurate and dynamic market alignment metrics.

### Effort Estimation

**Large.** This involves integrating external data sources, enhancing existing data processing, and updating prompt generation logic. Researching and selecting reliable data sources will also take time. Estimated time: 3-5 days.

issue.title: bug: Concatenated technology stacks lack separators

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: ux
labels.description: Related to User Experience design and testing.

labels.name: content
labels.description: Related to content generation, quality, and analysis.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

When displaying lists of technologies or skills (e.g., within project descriptions or skill categories), the items are concatenated without proper separators (e.g., commas, bullet points). This makes the lists difficult to read and understand, degrading the overall user experience of the CV.

### Technical Analysis

This issue likely originates from the JavaScript code responsible for rendering these lists:

-   **`assets/script.js`:** Specifically, the `initializeSkillsSection()` function and potentially other functions that dynamically generate HTML for displaying skills or project technologies (e.g., within `initializeProjectsSection()` or `initializeExperienceSection()`). The problem is likely in how arrays of strings (representing skills or technologies) are joined together before being inserted into the HTML.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Clear Separators:** All lists of technologies or skills are rendered with appropriate and readable separators (e.g., ", ", " â€¢ ", or as distinct list items).
-   **Readability:** The visual presentation of technology stacks is significantly improved.
-   **Consistency:** Separator usage is consistent across all sections of the CV where lists of technologies/skills are displayed.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Identify Rendering Points:**
    *   Examine `assets/script.js` to pinpoint all locations where arrays of skills or technologies are converted into displayable strings.
    *   Look for `map()` and `join()` operations on arrays like `exp.technologies` or `categorySkills`.
2.  **Implement Proper Joining:**
    *   Modify the JavaScript code to ensure that when joining array elements, a suitable separator (e.g., `', '`) is explicitly used.
    *   Alternatively, consider rendering each skill/technology as a separate `<li>` element within a `<ul>` for better semantic structure and styling control (this might also help with Issue #73).
3.  **Test with Sample Data:** Verify the fix by checking various sections of the CV that display technology lists.

### Dependency Mapping

-   This issue is primarily a frontend rendering bug. It might have a slight overlap with Issue #73 (Bullet points are presented as plain paragraphs with hyphens) if the solution involves using proper `<ul>`/`<li>` structures.

### Effort Estimation

**Small.** This is likely a straightforward fix involving minor adjustments to string concatenation or HTML generation in JavaScript. Estimated time: 0.5 - 1 day.

` tags or `

`s with hyphens, instead of proper `
    ` (unordered list) and `
  • ` (list item) tags. * **Relevant files:** `assets/script.js` (specifically functions that render experience details, skills, etc.) and potentially `cv-generator.js` if it's involved in the HTML generation. 2. **Missing or Overridden CSS Styling:** Even if correct `
      `/`
    • ` tags are used, the CSS might be overriding default list styles or failing to apply appropriate bullet point styling. * **Relevant files:** `assets/styles.css` and `assets/watch-me-work.css` (though less likely for the main CV). ### Acceptance Criteria - **Proper List Rendering:** All intended bullet points (e.g., experience details, skill items) are rendered as standard list items with appropriate bullet markers (e.g., circles, discs, squares). - **Consistent Styling:** Bullet point styling is consistent across all sections of the CV. - **Readability:** The visual presentation of lists is improved, enhancing the overall readability of the CV. - **Cross-Browser Compatibility:** Bullet points render correctly across major web browsers. ### Implementation Approach 1. **Inspect HTML Output:** * Use browser developer tools to inspect the generated HTML structure of a section that should contain bullet points (e.g., an experience entry's details). * Verify if `

      • ` tags are being used correctly. 2. **Review JavaScript Rendering Logic:** * Examine the JavaScript functions in `assets/script.js` that are responsible for dynamically inserting content into the CV (e.g., `initializeExperienceSection`, `initializeSkillsSection`). * Ensure that when bullet points are expected, the JavaScript constructs proper `
          ` and `
        • ` elements. 3. **Review CSS Styling:** * If the HTML structure is correct, inspect `assets/styles.css` to ensure that default list styles are not being reset or that custom styling for `ul` and `li` elements is correctly applied. * Look for properties like `list-style-type`, `padding-left`, and `margin-left` that might affect bullet point rendering. 4. **Test with Sample Data:** Use the existing CV data to test the rendering of various list types. ### Dependency Mapping - This issue is primarily a frontend rendering bug and does not have direct dependencies on other major backend or AI-related issues. ### Effort Estimation **Small.** This is likely a straightforward fix involving minor adjustments to HTML generation logic or CSS styling. Estimated time: 0.5 - 1 day.

issue.title: bug: activity-summary.json references missing data files

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: analyzer
labels.description: Related to activity analysis and data processing

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: data-integrity
labels.description: Related to ensuring accuracy and consistency of data

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The `activity-summary.json` file, which aggregates activity metrics, is referencing data files that do not exist or are not correctly linked. This leads to data integrity issues and potentially inaccurate activity metrics within the CV generation process.

### Technical Analysis

-   **`activity-analyzer.js` (`.github/scripts/activity-analyzer.js`):** This script is responsible for generating `activity-summary.json`. The problem likely lies in how this script identifies, processes, and references the underlying activity data files.
-   **`cv-generator.js` (`.github/scripts/cv-generator.js`):** This script consumes `activity-summary.json`. It expects certain data files to be present and correctly referenced within the summary. The issue might manifest as errors during CV generation or as missing/incorrect activity metrics in the generated CV.
-   **Data Files:** The missing data files are likely the raw activity logs or processed intermediate files that `activity-analyzer.js` is supposed to summarize.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Correct Data Referencing:** `activity-summary.json` accurately references all necessary underlying data files, and these files are present and accessible.
-   **No Missing File Errors:** The CV generation process (specifically when consuming `activity-summary.json`) no longer reports errors related to missing data files.
-   **Accurate Activity Metrics:** The activity metrics derived from `activity-summary.json` are correct and reflect the actual activity data.
-   **Automated Validation:** A mechanism is in place to validate the integrity of `activity-summary.json` and its references.
-   **Unit Test Coverage:** Relevant unit tests are added or updated for `activity-analyzer.js` to ensure correct data referencing and summary generation.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Root Cause Analysis:**
    *   Examine `activity-analyzer.js` to understand how it constructs `activity-summary.json` and its references to other data files.
    *   Verify the expected location and naming conventions of the data files it attempts to reference.
    *   Reproduce the error by running `activity-analyzer.js` and `cv-generator.js` with sample data.
2.  **Data File Management:**
    *   Ensure that the data files being referenced by `activity-summary.json` are consistently generated and stored in the expected locations.
    *   If necessary, modify `activity-analyzer.js` to correctly handle the paths and existence of these files.
3.  **Update `activity-analyzer.js`:**
    *   Implement robust checks within `activity-analyzer.js` to verify the existence of referenced files before including them in the summary.
    *   Consider adding a mechanism to log warnings or errors if files are missing during summary generation.
4.  **Enhance `cv-generator.js` (if needed):**
    *   Ensure `cv-generator.js` gracefully handles cases where `activity-summary.json` might be incomplete or malformed (though the primary fix should be in `activity-analyzer.js`).
5.  **Develop Unit Tests:**
    *   Add unit tests to `activity-analyzer.js` that specifically test the generation of `activity-summary.json` and its references.
    *   Test cases should include scenarios where referenced files are present and where they are missing.

### Dependency Mapping

-   This issue is a critical bug fix and is foundational for accurate activity metrics. It may impact other features that rely on correct activity data.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** Requires investigation into existing data generation and consumption logic, and careful implementation of file management and error handling. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

comment.body:
âœ… **RESOLVED** - Fixed race condition in activity-analyzer.js

**Root Cause**: Activity-summary.json was being created with references to data files before those files were actually written to disk, causing intermittent missing file errors.

**Solution Implemented**:
- Modified `saveAnalysisResults()` method to create all referenced files **atomically** before updating the summary
- Added proper directory structure creation with `{ recursive: true }`
- Implemented consistent timestamp handling to prevent filename mismatches
- Enhanced logging for better visibility into file creation process

**Files Changed**:
- `.github/scripts/activity-analyzer.js` - Enhanced to create activity/, metrics/, and trends/ data files

**Testing**: Verified all referenced files now exist and are accessible by dependent systems.

**Impact**: Eliminates data pipeline failures and ensures reliable file references for CV enhancement system.

---

issue.title: bug: Print/Download PDF buttons are non-functional

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: generator
labels.description: Related to CV generation process

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: ux
labels.description: Related to User Experience design and testing.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

The "Print CV" and "Download PDF" buttons on the CV interface are non-functional, preventing users from easily obtaining a physical copy or a portable digital version of their CV.

### Technical Analysis

-   **Print Button:** The "Print CV" button in `index.html` uses `onclick="window.print()"`. This is a standard browser function. If it's not working, potential causes include:
    *   JavaScript errors preventing the `onclick` event from firing.
    *   Browser-specific security restrictions.
    *   Conflicting CSS (`@media print`) that might hide content or make it unprintable.
-   **Download PDF Button:** The "Download PDF" button in `index.html` links directly to `assets/adrian-wedd-cv.pdf`. If this is non-functional, the most likely causes are:
    *   The PDF file (`assets/adrian-wedd-cv.pdf`) is missing from the repository or not being generated correctly.
    *   The path to the PDF file is incorrect.
-   **PDF Generation:** The `cv-generator.js` script (documented in `docs/jsdoc_output/github_scripts_cv-generator.js.html`) contains a `generatePDF()` function. This suggests that the PDF is intended to be pre-generated or generated as part of a build process. The non-functionality might stem from a failure in this generation process.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Print Functionality:** Clicking the "Print CV" button successfully opens the browser's print dialog with the CV content.
-   **PDF Download Functionality:** Clicking the "Download PDF" button successfully initiates the download of a valid PDF file of the CV.
-   **PDF Content Accuracy:** The downloaded PDF accurately reflects the content and styling of the online CV.
-   **Error Handling:** Appropriate feedback is provided to the user if print or download operations fail.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Verify Print Functionality:**
    *   Test `window.print()` directly in the browser console on `index.html`.
    *   Inspect `assets/script.js` for any JavaScript errors that might be preventing event handlers from firing.
    *   Review `assets/styles.css` for any `@media print` rules that might be inadvertently hiding content.
2.  **Verify PDF File Existence and Path:**
    *   Manually check if `assets/adrian-wedd-cv.pdf` exists in the repository.
    *   Confirm the path in `index.html` is correct.
3.  **Investigate PDF Generation Process:**
    *   Examine `cv-generator.js` and any associated build scripts or GitHub Actions workflows that are responsible for generating `adrian-wedd-cv.pdf`.
    *   Ensure the PDF generation process is running successfully and placing the file in the correct location.
    *   If the PDF is not being generated, debug the `generatePDF()` function and its dependencies (e.g., Puppeteer or similar headless browser tools).

### Dependency Mapping

-   This issue is primarily a frontend functionality bug, but its resolution may depend on the successful execution of backend PDF generation processes.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** The print functionality might be a quick fix, but debugging and ensuring the PDF generation process is robust could take more time. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

issue.body:
### Problem Statement

When displaying lists of technologies or skills (e.g., within project descriptions or skill categories), the items are concatenated without proper separators (e.g., commas, bullet points). This makes the lists difficult to read and understand, degrading the overall user experience of the CV.

### Technical Analysis

This issue likely originates from the JavaScript code responsible for rendering these lists:

-   **`assets/script.js`:** Specifically, the `initializeSkillsSection()` function and potentially other functions that dynamically generate HTML for displaying skills or project technologies (e.g., within `initializeProjectsSection()` or `initializeExperienceSection()`).     *   Examine `assets/script.js` to pinpoint all locations where arrays of skills or technologies are converted into displayable strings.

### Dependency Mapping

issue.title: ðŸš€ feat: Implement Git Flow Development Workflow for Production Safety

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: ci-cd
labels.description: Related to Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: workflow
labels.description: Related to workflow design and execution

issue.body:
## Problem Statement

Currently, all development work is committed directly to the `main` branch, which poses risks to production stability:

- **Production Impact**: Direct commits to main can break the live CV website
- **CI/CD Disruption**: Failed builds affect scheduled enhancement pipelines  
- **No Testing Environment**: Changes aren't tested in isolation before deployment
- **Rollback Complexity**: Difficult to revert problematic changes quickly

## Proposed Solution: Git Flow Development Workflow

### Branch Strategy

**Production Branches:**
- `main` - Production-ready code, protected branch
- `release/*` - Release preparation branches for final testing

**Development Branches:**  
- `develop` - Integration branch for features, the new "default" branch
- `feature/*` - Individual feature development branches
- `hotfix/*` - Emergency fixes that need immediate production deployment

### Workflow Implementation

#### 1. Branch Protection Rules
```yaml
# .github/branch-protection.yml
main:
  protection_rules:
    required_reviews: 1
    dismiss_stale_reviews: true
    require_code_owner_reviews: true
    required_status_checks:
      - "CI/CD Pipeline"
      - "PDF Generation Test"
      - "Content Validation"
    enforce_admins: false
    restrictions:
      push: []
      merge: ["adrianwedd"]
```

#### 2. Development Environment Setup
- **Staging Environment**: `https://adrianwedd.github.io/cv-dev` (from develop branch)
- **Feature Previews**: Deploy feature branches to `https://adrianwedd.github.io/cv-preview-{branch}`
- **Production**: `https://adrianwedd.github.io/cv` (from main branch only)

#### 3. Enhanced CI/CD Pipeline

**Development Pipeline** (develop branch):
- Run every 2 hours for continuous testing
- Deploy to staging environment
- Full AI enhancement and testing
- Generate test reports

**Production Pipeline** (main branch):
- Run every 6 hours (current schedule)
- Deploy to production only after all checks pass
- Include rollback capabilities

#### 4. Automated Quality Gates

**Pre-merge Checks:**
- âœ… All tests pass
- âœ… No ESLint errors
- âœ… PDF generation succeeds
- âœ… AI enhancement validation
- âœ… No broken links or missing assets
- âœ… Performance benchmarks met

#### 5. Development Workflow Process

**For New Features:**
```bash
# 1. Create feature branch from develop
git checkout develop
git pull origin develop
git checkout -b feature/new-enhancement

# 2. Develop and test locally
npm run test
npm run lint

# 3. Push and create PR to develop
git push origin feature/new-enhancement
gh pr create --base develop --title "feat: new enhancement"

# 4. After PR approval, merge to develop
# 5. Develop deploys to staging automatically
# 6. When ready for production, create release PR from develop to main
```

**For Hotfixes:**
```bash
# 1. Create hotfix branch from main
git checkout main
git checkout -b hotfix/critical-bug-fix

# 2. Fix and test
# 3. Create PR to main (expedited review process)
# 4. After merge, cherry-pick to develop
```

### Implementation Plan

#### Phase 1: Infrastructure (Week 1)
- [ ] Create `develop` branch from current `main`
- [ ] Set up branch protection rules
- [ ] Configure staging deployment workflow
- [ ] Update repository settings

#### Phase 2: CI/CD Enhancement (Week 2) 
- [ ] Duplicate current workflow for develop branch
- [ ] Add staging environment variables
- [ ] Implement automated quality gates
- [ ] Create PR templates with checklists

#### Phase 3: Documentation & Training (Week 3)
- [ ] Update contributing guidelines
- [ ] Create workflow documentation
- [ ] Add PR and issue templates
- [ ] Document rollback procedures

#### Phase 4: Feature Preview System (Week 4)
- [ ] Implement feature branch deployments
- [ ] Add preview URL generation
- [ ] Create cleanup automation for old previews

### Benefits

**ðŸ›¡ï¸ Production Safety:**
- Protected main branch prevents accidental deployments
- Quality gates ensure only tested code reaches production
- Easy rollback capabilities

**ðŸš€ Development Velocity:**
- Parallel feature development without conflicts
- Staging environment for comprehensive testing
- Automated validation reduces manual overhead

**ðŸ“Š Quality Assurance:**
- All changes reviewed before production
- Automated testing catches issues early
- Performance monitoring ensures optimal UX

**ðŸ”„ Operational Excellence:**
- Clear process for emergency fixes
- Audit trail of all production changes
- Reduced risk of breaking scheduled pipelines

### Success Metrics

- **Zero production incidents** from development work
- **100% uptime** for scheduled enhancement pipelines
- **<2 hour** time-to-fix for critical issues
- **Staging-production parity** maintained at 99.9%

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `main` branch is protected with required reviews
- [ ] `develop` branch serves as integration branch
- [ ] Staging environment mirrors production setup
- [ ] CI/CD pipeline works for both develop and main
- [ ] Documentation updated with new workflow
- [ ] All contributors trained on new process

## Implementation Priority

**P1: High** - This is critical infrastructure that will prevent production issues and enable safer, faster development cycles.

---

*This enhancement will establish industry-standard development practices while maintaining the AI-powered CV system's reliability and performance.*
